wp4.staff.models¶

Classes

Person(*args, **kwargs)

Replacement for original StaffPerson class which was linked to User as a one-to-one via “profile” attribute.
class wp4.staff.models.Person(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Replacement for original StaffPerson class which was linked to User as a one-to-one via “profile” attribute.

This represents any person that is a member of staff (medical, administrative, academic, etc) and therefore not a patient (see compare.Patient for that). Not all people with records here will be active users of the system

We’ll rely on Django-Reversion to capture changes to records, and thus the audit trail.

Parameters

  • id (django.db.models.AutoField) – “ID”

  • password (django.db.models.CharField) – “password”

  • last_login (django.db.models.DateTimeField) – “last login”

  • is_superuser (django.db.models.BooleanField) – “superuser status” - Designates that this user has all permissions without explicitly assigning them.

  • username (django.db.models.CharField) – “username” - Required. 150 characters or fewer. Letters, digits and @/./+/-/_ only.

  • first_name (django.db.models.CharField) – “first name”

  • last_name (django.db.models.CharField) – “last name”

  • email (django.db.models.EmailField) – “email address”

  • is_staff (django.db.models.BooleanField) – “staff status” - Designates whether the user can log into this admin site.

  • is_active (django.db.models.BooleanField) – “active” - Designates whether this user should be treated as active. Unselect this instead of deleting accounts.

  • date_joined (django.db.models.DateTimeField) – “date joined”

  • telephone (django.db.models.CharField) – “Telephone Number”

  • based_at_id (django.db.models.ForeignKey) – “Location” - Link to a primary hospital location for the member of staff

telephone¶

Contents validated against phone_regex r'^\+?1?\d{9,15}$'

based_at¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

exception DoesNotExist¶
class Hospital(*args, **kwargs)¶

Simple helper class to hold information related to the various project and non-project locations. Currently referenced from Donor, OrganAllocation, RetrievalTeam, Person

This data is so generic and widely used that there should be no restrictions on geography, and everyone should be able to view it.

Parameters

  • id (django.db.models.AutoField) – “ID”

  • record_locked (django.db.models.BooleanField) – “record locked” - Locked by the admin team. This can only be reversed by the System Administrator

  • live (livefield.fields.LiveField) – “live”

  • name (django.db.models.CharField) – “Hospital Name”

  • country (django.db.models.PositiveSmallIntegerField) – “Country”

  • is_active (django.db.models.BooleanField) – “Active” - Not presently used/implemented. For legacy data when a location closes for use

  • is_project_site (django.db.models.BooleanField) – “Project site”

organallocation_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

groups¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.
